          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');
        </script><head><meta charSet="utf-8"/><meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width"/><link rel="shortcut icon" href="https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/favicon.7bc3d920.ico"/><script>

        window.eventsToSend = window.eventsToSend || []

          name: "page_rendering",
          timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
          value: JSON.stringify({
            time: performance?.now()
          })
        })
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Failed to push page render event:", error)

It highlights key developments in the Russian cybercrime market, including the emergence of new trojans and sophisticated attack strategies leveraging social engineering. class="metadata Metadata_root__EZem9" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="title Metadata_title__aM3nZ Heading_h1__jLBB4 Heading_heading___M8rU">Hi-Tech Crime Trends 2016</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2017-03-30 16:21:02 UTC">Mar 30, 2017</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC Text_medium__TH6gG Text_secondary__o6d_E Likes_root__WVQ1_" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">997<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span><button type="button" class="ai-tag unstyled-button AITag_tag__Xx37c" data-cy="ai-tag" aria-describedby="aiTag-description" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R3497d6:" popovertarget=":R3497d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R3497d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="position-anchor:--popover-R3497d6"></div></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="Group-IB" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Group-IB"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-Group-IB-48x48.jpg?cb=1523415001" alt="Group-IB" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>Group-IB</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">The document reviews hi-tech crime trends from Q2 2015 to Q1 2016, focusing on the rise of targeted attacks on banks, the expansion of the Android trojan market, and the increasing threat of ransomware and attacks on critical infrastructure. It highlights key developments in the Russian cybercrime market, including the emergence of new trojans and sophisticated attack strategies leveraging social engineering. The report concludes with recommendations for prevention and response measures against these evolving cyber threats.</p></div><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq TARGETED ATTACKS ON BANKS AS A GLOBAL THREAT
&gt;&gt;&gt; Group-IB.COM

ATMs and SWIFT
TREND NO.2
GROUPS REFOCUS FROM COMPANIES TO BANKS
LURK
Core Banking Systems
CORKOW
POS terminals, ATMs,
trading terminals
ANUNAK
Core Banking Systems,
SWIFT, ATMs,
payment gateways,
POS terminals
BUHTRAP
Core Banking Systems
GROUP-IB.COM/REPORTS
CURRENT
soon!
&gt;&gt;&gt; Group-IB.COM
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/gib-en-170330162103/85/Hi-Tech-Crime-Trends-2016-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/gib-en-170330162103/85/Hi-Tech-Crime-Trends-2016-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/gib-en-170330162103/75/Hi-Tech-Crime-Trends-2016-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/gib-en-170330162103/85/Hi-Tech-Crime-Trends-2016-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:1024 / 768" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="FORECAST
TARGETED ATTACKS ON BANKS
CHANGE IN
FOCUS
Active groups
specializing in attacks
on companies will
threaten banks
EXPANDING IN
GEOGRAPHY
Hackers attacking Russian
banks will move their
activity to other regions
worldwide
BROADENING
COMPETENCIES
Groups attacking ATMs will
perform cyber thefts on
SWIFT system
PHISHING
MAILOUTS
The key vector to infect
banking networks is
phishing emails
INVOLVING
INSIDERS
Hackers devote more
time searching for
insiders (contacts,
application launch,
consulting on system
operation)
LEGITIMATE
TOOLS
Criminals choose
legitimate or free tools to
perform attacks
Arrests of Russian-speaking hacker groups
have a significant impact on
the global landscape of banking threats
&gt;&gt;&gt; Group-IB.COM

companies

to steal money from

functionality

to BANKS

AUTOMATED FRAUD
Automatic fraud on
ANDROID
Criminals will attack both
companies and people
using web injects to
replace payment details.
ROBOT-BASED
VISHING
Automated vishing attacks
will be adjusted to bypass
SMS verification and will
become more popular
AUTOMATED
PHISHING
The function to bypass
SMS verification will make
mobile Trojans the most
dangerous threat to the
majority of banks.
With their wide distribution and automation
PHISHING and ANDROID Trojans will finally replace PC
Trojans.

BOTNETS FOR DDOS ATTACKS
MOVE AWAY
AMPLIFIERS

CharGen and other types
are less actively used

REAPPEAR
Criminals often use Linux
servers and simple IoT
devices to create botnets
SOURCE CODES
ARE PUBLISHED
Lizard Stresser and Mirai
were released publicly
Dynamic IP addresses
No antivirus installed
24-hours access to the Internet
IoT devices are perfect bots
Difficult to update and eliminate
known vulnerabilities
Passwords set by default

450 Gbps
2016
602 Gbps

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/gib-en-170330162103/85/Hi-Tech-Crime-Trends-2016-15-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/gib-en-170330162103/85/Hi-Tech-Crime-Trends-2016-15-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/gib-en-170330162103/75/Hi-Tech-Crime-Trends-2016-15-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/gib-en-170330162103/85/Hi-Tech-Crime-Trends-2016-15-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide16" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:1024 / 768" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-15" alt="FORECAST
INCREASE IN INCIDENTS WITH RANSOMWARE
Wide variety of
targets
Mobile and IoT devices,
cloud storages
Average ransom will
increase
Newer ransomware versions
will deliberately target key
business assets, which will
significantly raise the price of
ransomware decryption keys
Pinpoint attack
The key target is companies
with critical business
processes, which cannot
spend time to recover them
and will pay ransoms
Worms
Ransomware will be
distributed as
cryptoworms to widely
spread threats and
cause significant
damage
Smoke Screens
Encrypting ransomware will
be used as a “distraction”
tool in conjunction with high-
profile targeted attacks, like
DDoS attacks used
previously
An increase in attacks will
stimulate the cyber risk
insurance segment, which in
turn will motivate criminals
&gt;&gt;&gt; Group-IB.COM

ATTACKS ON CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE
Public
information
Information on
successful attacks will
leak to journalists
because of their
political subtext
Popularization
Public reaction to
successful attacks will
provoke increased interest
from cyber-armies and
terrorists
Cyber-armies
Cyber-armies will attack
critical infrastructure
facilities
Goal: espionage and
control capability
Terrorists
Cyber-terrorists will
target critical
infrastructure facilities
Goal: public attention,
human losses
ONLINE
RECRUITMENT
Cyber-terrorists will
actively use the Internet
for propagation and
recruitments of technical
specialists, who are able
to perform targeted
attacks
arrests
and recruitment
Hackers arrested for
targeted attacks on
companies will be
recruited by the
Government

class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Group-IB">Group-IB</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Group-IB report on high-tech crime trends from 2015 highlights a decrease in cyber-crime losses in Russia alongside an increase in total attacks, particularly against mobile banking systems. Hackers are increasingly targeting Western financial institutions due to economic conditions, and new tools and methodologies have emerged to facilitate these attacks. Significant developments include the identification of new criminal groups, advances in mobile trojans, and the introduction of tailored malware for trading systems.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Group-IB">Group-IB</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Group-IB report on high-tech crime trends for 2014 outlines the rise of various criminal activities facilitated by modern technology, including fraud, drug trafficking, and cyberattacks. It highlights the increasing sophistication of cybercriminals, the emergence of the shadow economy, and the need for enhanced awareness and countermeasures among society, businesses, and governments. The report also emphasizes the significant role of Russian-speaking hackers in global high-tech crime and forecasts future trends in cyber threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R13lh7d6:" popovertarget=":R13lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R13lh7d6"><a slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/bluesme">- Mark - Fullbright</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document outlines security predictions for 2014, highlighting that mobile banking will face increased man-in-the-middle attacks, and basic two-step verification will become inadequate. It notes the rise in targeted attacks using sophisticated methodologies and the prediction of a significant data breach occurring every month, particularly exploiting vulnerabilities in unsupported software like Java 6 and Windows XP. Furthermore, the document emphasizes the challenges posed by the deep web to law enforcement and the growing public distrust in privacy due to state-sponsored monitoring activities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13lh7d6"></div><div class="separator RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Rp quarterly-threat-q3-2013</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Rp quarterly-threat-q3-2013 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfd4lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfd4lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rfd4lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfd4lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfd4lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ssusered8d1e">Комсс Файквэе</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document summarizes McAfee&#x27;s Threats Report for the third quarter of 2013. Some key points:

- Mobile malware increased 33% while overall new malware exceeded 20 million. New ransomware and rootkits also rose. 

- Digital currencies like Bitcoin are increasingly used by cybercriminals for money laundering and anonymous transactions on dark web markets. The shutdown of Silk Road prompted new illegal sites.

- The &quot;Deep Web&quot; contains unregulated online markets selling illegal drugs, weapons, credit cards, and even murder-for-hire services accessible through Tor and paid with Bitcoin. 

- Hacktivism and political hacking increased, while spam volume reached its highest level since 2010. Browser</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R15lh7d6:" popovertarget=":R15lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R15lh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/fraud-abuse-report-2020-by-arkose-labsfraud-report-q1-2020/227467366"><span class="sr-only">Fraud &amp; Abuse Report 2020 by Arkose LabsFraud report q1 2020</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Fraud &amp; Abuse Report 2020 by Arkose LabsFraud report q1 2020</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Fraud &amp; Abuse Report 2020 by Arkose LabsFraud report q1 2020 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfd5lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfd5lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rfd5lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfd5lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfd5lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JeffMartinez4">Jeff Martinez</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Q1 2020 Fraud and Abuse Report from Arkose Labs reveals a significant increase in both human-driven and automated fraud attacks, with human-driven attacks growing by 90% compared to the previous quarter. The report highlights that fraudsters are adapting their tactics, utilizing sophisticated tools and techniques to blend in with legitimate traffic, especially during peak shopping seasons. It emphasizes the need for organizations to adopt a zero-tolerance approach to fraud prevention to effectively combat the escalating fraud landscape.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-5" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R16lh7d6:" popovertarget=":R16lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R16lh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">RSA Monthly Online Fraud Report -- December 2014</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save RSA Monthly Online Fraud Report -- December 2014 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfd6lh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfd6lh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rfd6lh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfd6lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfd6lh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/emcacademics">EMC</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">A new malware called Lusypos is being sold in underground forums, which specializes in stealing credit card data from point-of-sale systems running on Windows. The report highlights the growing risk of POS malware in the U.S. as merchants prepare for EMV compliance, alongside a significant rise in phishing attacks during the holiday season, costing organizations approximately $594 million in losses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16lh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16lh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div It saw a rise in formjacking attacks that steal payment card data, though cryptojacking activity declined along with cryptocurrency values. Ransomware infections decreased overall but rose for enterprises. Living off the land attacks using tools like PowerShell increased substantially. RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the key findings from the 2007 Web Hacking Incidents Database annual report. It finds that over 40% of reported attacks were aimed at stealing sensitive personal information, likely for profit. Additionally, around 23% of incidents involved website defacement, with about half of those being for political messages. In general, around 67% of attacks appeared aimed at financial gain through theft of data, planting malware, or spam. However, the database only recorded 80 incidents that met its criteria, so the analysis is limited and based on percentages rather than absolute numbers.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1alh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1alh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-10" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1blh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1blh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1blh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/rsa-fraud-report-january-2013/16500371"><span class="sr-only">The Year in Phishing - The RSA anti-fraud command center reported that the volume of attacks continues to be a persistent threat, showing a record year with heightened phishing activities across mobile and social media platforms. The outlook for 2013 anticipates further growth in attacks as cybercriminals adapt to changing user behaviors and exploit the rising use of mobile applications.</span></div></div><div class="" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Ransomware became a major cyberthreat in 2016, especially in the United States. Ransomware payments increased 771% from 2015 to 2016. The healthcare and education industries were among the most affected. In 2017, experts predict that ransomware will continue to spread rapidly across more devices and sectors. New variants will emerge using improved encryption and different delivery methods. Ransomware criminals are expected to make over $5 billion. Strong backups remain the best defense against ransomware attacks.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1clh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" aria-controls=":Rfdelh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfdelh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rfdelh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfdelh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfdelh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/posselist">LUMINATIVE MEDIA/PROJECT COUNSEL MEDIA GROUP</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The criminal hacking group Fin7, which was behind the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, has set up a fake cybersecurity company called Bastion Secure to recruit new technical talent. Bastion Secure&#x27;s job postings and website appear legitimate, but researchers traced it back to Fin7. One potential recruit grew suspicious when asked to install hacking tools and collect network information without explanation. By impersonating real companies, ransomware groups are able to expand their operations and access more skilled workers, showing how these criminal networks are becoming increasingly professionalized.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1elh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1elh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 Файквэе</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document summarizes a mobile threat report for Q3 2013. It finds that 252 of the 259 new mobile threat families and variants discovered were for Android, with trojans making up the largest percentage at 88%. It also notes an increasing trend of profit-motivated mobile malware, with 81.1% of new threats aiming to generate money through unauthorized SMS messages. The report discusses recent developments like the identification of the creator of the Pincer Android banking trojan and the emergence of tools that simplify inserting malware into legitimate apps.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1flh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1flh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-15" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1glh7d6:" popovertarget=":R1glh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1glh7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/supersized-security-threats-can-you-stop-2016-from-repeating/74985512"><span class="sr-only">Supersized Security Threats – Can You Stop 2016 from Repeating?</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:15" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Supersized Security Threats – Can You Stop 2016 from Repeating?</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Supersized Security Threats – Can You Stop 2016 from Repeating? Despite a slight rise in security events among monitored clients, the average number of attacks decreased, and ransomware tactics evolved, focusing on business targets for higher profits. Key industries affected included financial services, information and communications, and manufacturing, with SQL injection attacks being predominant across sectors.</span></div></div><div class="" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document summarizes key findings from a report on cyber threats targeting the financial services sector. The top three findings are:

1. Financial services encounters security incidents 300% more frequently than other industries due to being a prime target. 

2. 33% of all reconnaissance and lure attacks target financial services, indicating large efforts to compromise financial institutions. 

3. Credential stealing attacks are prominent, with the top threats like Rerdom, Vawtrak, and Geodo having credential theft capabilities. Geodo is seen 400% more in financial services.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jlh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1jlh7d6"></div><div slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/RoenBranham">Roen Branham</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">A malware known as Grifthorse has impacted over 10 million Android users by secretly subscribing them to premium mobile services, leading to unauthorized charges on their bills. Researchers have identified more than 130 Grifthorse applications available on Google Play and other stores, utilizing deceptive tactics to evade detection and bombard users with phony prize notifications. With its sophisticated techniques, Grifthorse has generated potentially hundreds of millions of euros from victims across 70 countries.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1klh7d6:" popover="auto" data-cy="slideshow-title">Estado del ransomware en 2020</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Estado del ransomware en 2020 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rfdllh7d6:" popovertarget=":Rfdllh7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rfdllh7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rfdllh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rfdllh7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/IngenieraDricSolucio">iDric Soluciones de TI y Seguridad Informática</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Sophos white paper, &#x27;The State of Ransomware 2020,&#x27; reports findings from a survey of 5,000 IT managers across 26 countries, revealing that 51% experienced ransomware attacks in the past year, with 73% of these attacks successfully encrypting data. It highlights that paying a ransom often doubles remediation costs, with 94% of affected organizations managing to recover their data, primarily via backups. The report also notes regional differences in ransomware experiences and the effectiveness of cybersecurity insurance, with public sector organizations facing fewer attacks compared to the private sector.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1llh7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1llh7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime to espionage, ransomware, and vulnerabilities associated with the Internet of Things (IoT). It emphasizes the significant role of government actions and collaborations between private sectors in combating cybercrime, as exemplified by the influence of cyber activities during the 2016 U.S. presidential election and various destructive attacks on critical infrastructure. SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the key findings of a study on the link between pirated software and cybersecurity breaches:

1) The study found that consumers and enterprises have a 33% chance of encountering malware when obtaining pirated software or buying a PC with pirated software pre-installed. A forensic analysis of 203 PCs found 61% were infected with malware. 

2) Consumers will spend $25 billion dealing with security issues caused by malware on pirated software in 2014. Enterprises will spend $491 billion, with $315 billion resulting from criminal organizations&#x27; activities. 

3) Asia Pacific will incur over 40% of worldwide consumer losses and over 45% of enterprise losses from malware on pir</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1olh7d6:" popover="auto" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the rise of &#x27;phish lockers,&#x27; a type of trojan used by cybercriminals to steal credentials by locking the user&#x27;s desktop and presenting phishing pages without traditional banking functionalities. Phish lockers have been primarily attacking banks in Latin America but are now spreading to new regions, employing basic methods for data theft and communication. SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document summarizes cyber threat trends in 2018 according to a Symantec report. It saw a rise in formjacking attacks that steal payment card data, though cryptojacking activity declined along with cryptocurrency values. Ransomware infections decreased overall but rose for enterprises. Living off the land attacks using tools like PowerShell increased substantially. Targeted attacks grew more sophisticated with groups targeting operational systems and destructive malware.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgm9i7d6:" popover="auto" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the key findings from the 2007 Web Hacking Incidents Database annual report. It finds that over 40% of reported attacks were aimed at stealing sensitive personal information, likely for profit. Additionally, around 23% of incidents involved website defacement, with about half of those being for political messages. In general, around 67% of attacks appeared aimed at financial gain through theft of data, planting malware, or spam. However, the database only recorded 80 incidents that met its criteria, so the analysis is limited and based on percentages rather than absolute numbers.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rh69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rh69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rhm9i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rhm9i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rhm9i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/rsa-fraud-report-january-2013/16500371"><span class="sr-only">The Year in Phishing - The RSA anti-fraud command center reported that the volume of attacks continues to be a persistent threat, showing a record year with heightened phishing activities across mobile and social media platforms. The outlook for 2013 anticipates further growth in attacks as cybercriminals adapt to changing user behaviors and exploit the rising use of mobile applications.</span></div></div><div class="" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Ransomware became a major cyberthreat in 2016, especially in the United States. Ransomware payments increased 771% from 2015 to 2016. The healthcare and education industries were among the most affected. In 2017, experts predict that ransomware will continue to spread rapidly across more devices and sectors. New variants will emerge using improved encryption and different delivery methods. Ransomware criminals are expected to make over $5 billion. Strong backups remain the best defense against ransomware attacks.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ri69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mj69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mj69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/posselist">LUMINATIVE MEDIA/PROJECT COUNSEL MEDIA GROUP</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The criminal hacking group Fin7, which was behind the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, has set up a fake cybersecurity company called Bastion Secure to recruit new technical talent. Bastion Secure&#x27;s job postings and website appear legitimate, but researchers traced it back to Fin7. One potential recruit grew suspicious when asked to install hacking tools and collect network information without explanation. By impersonating real companies, ransomware groups are able to expand their operations and access more skilled workers, showing how these criminal networks are becoming increasingly professionalized.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rj69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rj69i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 Файквэе</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document summarizes a mobile threat report for Q3 2013. It finds that 252 of the 259 new mobile threat families and variants discovered were for Android, with trojans making up the largest percentage at 88%. It also notes an increasing trend of profit-motivated mobile malware, with 81.1% of new threats aiming to generate money through unauthorized SMS messages. The report discusses recent developments like the identification of the creator of the Pincer Android banking trojan and the emergence of tools that simplify inserting malware into legitimate apps.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rjm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rjm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rk69i7d6:" popovertarget=":Rk69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rk69i7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/supersized-security-threats-can-you-stop-2016-from-repeating/74985512"><span class="sr-only">Supersized Security Threats – Can You Stop 2016 from Repeating?</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Supersized Security Threats – Can You Stop 2016 from Repeating?</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Supersized Security Threats – Can You Stop 2016 from Repeating? for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mk69i7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mk69i7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mk69i7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mk69i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mk69i7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ValerieLanzone">Valerie Lanzone</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence Index 2017 reports a significant increase in data breaches in 2016, with over four billion records compromised. Despite a slight rise in security events among monitored clients, the average number of attacks decreased, and ransomware tactics evolved, focusing on business targets for higher profits. Key industries affected included financial services, information and communications, and manufacturing, with SQL injection attacks being predominant across sectors.</span></div></div><div class="" The top three findings are:

1. Financial services encounters security incidents 300% more frequently than other industries due to being a prime target. 

2. 33% of all reconnaissance and lure attacks target financial services, indicating large efforts to compromise financial institutions. 

3. Credential stealing attacks are prominent, with the top threats like Rerdom, Vawtrak, and Geodo having credential theft capabilities. Geodo is seen 400% more in financial services.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rlm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rlm9i7d6"></div><div SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">A malware known as Grifthorse has impacted over 10 million Android users by secretly subscribing them to premium mobile services, leading to unauthorized charges on their bills. Researchers have identified more than 130 Grifthorse applications available on Google Play and other stores, utilizing deceptive tactics to evade detection and bombard users with phony prize notifications. With its sophisticated techniques, Grifthorse has generated potentially hundreds of millions of euros from victims across 70 countries.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rm69i7d6:" popover="auto" class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Sophos white paper, &#x27;The State of Ransomware 2020,&#x27; reports findings from a survey of 5,000 IT managers across 26 countries, revealing that 51% experienced ransomware attacks in the past year, with 73% of these attacks successfully encrypting data. It highlights that paying a ransom often doubles remediation costs, with 94% of affected organizations managing to recover their data, primarily via backups. The report also notes regional differences in ransomware experiences and the effectiveness of cybersecurity insurance, with public sector organizations facing fewer attacks compared to the private sector.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rmm9i7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rmm9i7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document summarizes key trends in cybercrime in 2017, including a massive 34,000% increase in coin mining detections as criminals shifted focus from ransomware. Ransomware detections remained high but did not break the 2016 record. Targeted banking Trojan Emotet reemerged and increased 2000%. The document also discusses the notable WannaCry and Petya attacks but notes they were exceptions and do not represent overall ransomware trends in 2017.</span></div></div><div class="" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Internet Security Threat Report (ISTR) for June 2017 highlights evolving cyber threats, including targeted attacks related to espionage, ransomware, and vulnerabilities associated with the Internet of Things (IoT). It emphasizes the significant role of government actions and collaborations between private sectors in combating cybercrime, as exemplified by the influence of cyber activities during the 2016 U.S. presidential election and various destructive attacks on critical infrastructure. Overall, the report calls for enhanced security measures across sectors to mitigate emerging threats and protect national security.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rnm9i7d6:" popover="auto" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MicrosoftAsia">Microsoft Asia</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the key findings of a study on the link between pirated software and cybersecurity breaches:

1) The study found that consumers and enterprises have a 33% chance of encountering malware when obtaining pirated software or buying a PC with pirated software pre-installed. A forensic analysis of 203 PCs found 61% were infected with malware. 

2) Consumers will spend $25 billion dealing with security issues caused by malware on pirated software in 2014. Enterprises will spend $491 billion, with $315 billion resulting from criminal organizations&#x27; activities. 

3) Asia Pacific will incur over 40% of worldwide consumer losses and over 45% of enterprise losses from malware on pir</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ro69i7d6:" popover="auto" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the rise of &#x27;phish lockers,&#x27; a type of trojan used by cybercriminals to steal credentials by locking the user&#x27;s desktop and presenting phishing pages without traditional banking functionalities. Phish lockers have been primarily attacking banks in Latin America but are now spreading to new regions, employing basic methods for data theft and communication. The report also highlights a significant increase in phishing attacks worldwide, with the U.S. remaining the most targeted country.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpm9i7d6:" popover="auto" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the low adoption rate of business intelligence (BI) at 22% and emphasizes the need for improved reporting optimization to enable successful transitions to Enterprise 4.0. It highlights the potential for report consolidation to enhance decision-making and reduce costs, making BI more accessible. The creation of data products is presented as a game-changing approach to transform data into actionable insights.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhmai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rhmai7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="alsoLiked-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Ri6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":Ri6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Ri6ai7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/sampling-strategies-to-control-misclassification-bias-in-longitudinal-udder-health-studies/73910186"><span class="sr-only">Sampling Strategies to Control Misclassification Bias in Longitudinal Udder H...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Sampling Strategies to Control Misclassification Bias in Longitudinal Udder H...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Sampling Strategies to Control Misclassification Bias in Longitudinal Udder H... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mi6ai7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mi6ai7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mi6ai7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mi6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mi6ai7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/dhaine">dhaine</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a study on sampling strategies to control misclassification bias in longitudinal udder health studies. The study uses simulations of 100 cohorts of 30 cows each over 2 time points to estimate the impact of selection and misclassification biases on incidence and associations. It finds that duplicate or triplicate sampling can help control biases, especially when prevalence is high and test sensitivity is fair. The best strategies are to improve test sensitivity at baseline and specificity at follow-up. Bias can be evaluated using the R package developed by the authors.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ri6ai7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Ri6ai7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div Mateu</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Un buen médico de familia prioriza la relación con el paciente y busca entender sus necesidades en vez de centrarse únicamente en la tecnología. Fomenta la libertad y responsabilidad en la toma de decisiones del paciente, así como la importancia de la comunicación empática. SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the evolution of the right to food as a legal entitlement, emphasizing the need for states to respect, protect, and fulfill this right, drawing on examples from various countries in Latin America. It identifies several challenges and barriers to enforcing food rights, including legal, political, and operational issues, while proposing civic actions and legal strategies to advance food security. method within machine learning and artificial intelligence. SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document outlines a training agenda for a cyber security conference held in August 2015. Day 1 covers topics like cyber crimes, the current situation in Indonesia and globally, and identifying threats and vulnerabilities. Day 2 focuses on information security strategies across organizations and envisioning the future state. Several sessions explore defining cyber crimes, common attack types like viruses and denial of service, and who carries out cyber crimes. The document also discusses trends like the growing cyber crime marketplace, risks to mobile devices, larger attacks on retailers and banks, and more advanced targeted threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rgmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rgmbi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" information technology threat predictions</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/prayukth1">Prayukth K V</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In 2014, there is an expected rise in cyber threats focusing on mobile, social, and cloud platforms, with particular concern over mobile malware and ransomware fueled by virtual currencies like Bitcoin. Advanced evasion techniques are anticipated, including stealth attacks on social media and exploitation of HTML5 vulnerabilities in apps and cloud services. The report highlights the need for vigilance as cybercriminals adapt and innovate their methods to target personal, corporate, and government assets.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rh6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rh6bi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rhmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rhmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rhmbi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/bluesme/sophos-securitythreatreport2014"><span class="sr-only">Sophos Security Threat Report 2014</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Sophos Security Threat Report 2014</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Sophos Security Threat Report 2014 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mhmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mhmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mhmbi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mhmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mhmbi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/bluesme">- Mark - Fullbright</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Botnets have grown larger, more resilient, and better camouflaged. They are finding new ways to generate revenue through ransomware and bitcoin mining. Android malware is also evolving, with threats becoming more sophisticated at avoiding detection and removal. While no single Android malware is dominant, the most widespread is Andr/BBridge-A, which has demonstrated longevity since first being detected in 2012. There are some signs of progress, such as Google improving Android security and the arrest of an exploit kit author, but threats continue advancing techniques.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rhmbi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Ri6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":Ri6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Ri6bi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/ss-76552280/76552280"><span class="sr-only">Хакеры data-cy="slideshow-title">Хакеры хотят ваш банк больше, чем ваших клиентов</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Хакеры хотят ваш банк больше, чем ваших клиентов for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mi6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mi6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mi6bi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mi6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mi6bi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/phdays">Positive Hack Days</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses targeted attacks on financial institutions. It provides information on:

1) Known targeted attackers like Cobalt, Corkow, and Anunak and their favorite targets like ATMs, card processing, and SWIFT systems. 

2) Future targeted attackers that may go after financial networks. 

3) The common targets of these attacks, which include corporate internet banking software, payment gateways, ATMs, trade terminals, and SWIFT/ARM CBR systems.

4) The malware delivery methods used by these groups, such as driveby downloads, pay-per-install, web hacks, phishing emails, and spear phishing.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ri6bi7d6:" 22</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/cheapsslsecurity">CheapSSLsecurity</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The April 2017 Internet Security Threat Report highlights a significant rise in cyber attacks characterized by increased ambition and simplicity, with malicious actors employing tactics such as spear-phishing and exploiting existing tools rather than sophisticated malware. Key issues include the emergence of ransomware, targeting financial institutions in large-scale heists, and a shift toward disruptive subversion and sabotage attacks, particularly in the context of political interference. The report emphasizes the growing threats from IoT devices and the continued reliance on email as the primary channel for cyber attacks.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rimbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rimbi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mj6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mj6bi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/AbdullahAlGhamdi4">Abdullah Al-Ghamdi</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">1. Sophos Labs predicts 10 cyber security trends for 2014, including attacks targeting cloud access through endpoints, mobile devices, and credentials as businesses increase cloud migration. 

2. Financial malware is expected to adopt techniques of advanced persistent threats normally used for cyber espionage, making them more difficult to detect. 

3. Android malware will become more complex, seeking new targets by using mobile devices as platforms to attack social networks and cloud services.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rj6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rj6bi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rjmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rjmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rjmbi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/manu-quintans-frank-ruiz-50-shades-of-crimeware-rooted-con-2014/33911487"><span class="sr-only">Manu Quintans &amp; They will discuss the evolution of cybercrime activities and infrastructure, including the rise of point of sale malware targeting payment card data, new mobile malware using TOR anonymity networks, and the growing use of cryptocurrencies. They will provide a detailed example of the 2013 Target breach that resulted in over 70 million customer records being stolen. The presentation will include a demonstration of malware samples.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rjmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rjmbi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rk6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rk6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rk6bi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/january-2014-wss-webinar-slides/29872490"><span class="sr-only">Website Security Threats - It discusses cybercrime statistics from the month including money earned by cybercriminals and numbers of stolen payment cards and user credentials. RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a CYREN webinar on mobile malware and phishing trends from Q2 2014. It finds that ransomware expanded to Android devices, along with banking malware targeting SMS messages. Zbot variants continued spreading through email attachments and Dropbox links. PDF and Word documents were also used to distribute malware. Phishing targeted World Cup-related brands and global banks. Spam levels decreased while pump-and-dump stock scams increased. The webinar reviewed CYREN&#x27;s security products and cloud-based threat intelligence designed to help partners.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rkmbi7d6:" popover="auto" Volume 19</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:10" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Symantec Internet Security Threat Report 2014 - Volume 19 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mlmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mlmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mlmbi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mlmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mlmbi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/symantec">Symantec</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document outlines the significant rise in data breaches and targeted attack campaigns throughout 2013, with mega breaches exposing over 552 million identities. Key contributors to breaches included hacking, insider threats, and accidental disclosures, particularly affecting the healthcare, education, and public sectors. The document also highlights the evolution of malware, particularly ransomware, and emphasizes the growing risks associated with mobile threats and the Internet of Things.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rlmbi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rlmbi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rm6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rm6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rm6bi7d6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/symantec-internet-security-threat-report-2009/3882874"><span class="sr-only">Symantec Internet Security Threat Report - 2009</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:11" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi"></div><div class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d"></div></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Symantec Internet Security Threat Report - 2009</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Symantec Internet Security Threat Report - 2009 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mm6bi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mm6bi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mm6bi7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mm6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mm6bi7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/guest6561cc">guest6561cc</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document is Symantec&#x27;s annual Global Internet Security Threat Report. It analyzes trends in threats, vulnerabilities, and other security issues from 2009. Some key findings include:

- Countries like the US, China, and India were major sources of malicious activity. Web-based attacks and phishing remained prevalent threats. 

- Vulnerabilities in browsers and browser plugins posed risks. Exploits targeting vulnerabilities in Java, Adobe Reader, and other widely used programs were common.

- The number of new malicious code increased significantly in 2009. Trojans and botnets were widely used. 

- Phishing targeted many industries, especially financial services. Automated phishing toolkits made phishing</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rm6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rm6bi7d6"></div><div SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Kaspersky Lab webinar discussed APT (Advanced Persistent Threat) predictions for 2015, highlighting trends such as the merging of cybercrime and APT, evolving malware techniques, and emerging threats to critical infrastructure. Key predictions include an increase in targeted attacks on banks, more sophisticated malware and evasion techniques, and the use of cloud services for data exfiltration. As APT groups become more fragmented and concerned about exposure, 2015 is expected to see the rise of mobile-specific threats and targeted surveillance through botnet operations.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Ro6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Ro6bi7d6"></div><div class="separator slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/prayukth1">Prayukth K V</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Cybercriminals prefer attacking bank customers directly rather than hacking banks. They do this through phishing emails with fake banking forms, spoofing of legitimate banking websites, and intercepting unprotected internet connections to steal users&#x27; financial credentials and data. Malware like Trojans also intercept keystrokes and screenshots to steal sensitive banking information from infected computers and mobile devices. Over 1.8 million users encountered financial malware in 2013, losing hundreds of millions of dollars to online financial fraud and theft.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rp6bi7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rp6bi7d6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_withBgOnHover__Tkyn2 SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rpmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":Rpmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rpmbi7d6"><a threat-landscape report by fortinet. for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mpmbi7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mpmbi7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mpmbi7d6"><span slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/RehamElsafarini">Reham Maher El-Safarini</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The H1 2020 Threat Landscape Report by FortiGuard Labs highlights significant cybersecurity developments amid the COVID-19 pandemic, indicating record vulnerability disclosures and active exploit challenges. Ransomware attacks surged, particularly against enterprise organizations, while web-based malware tactics became more prevalent. The report emphasizes the importance of maintaining robust defenses, especially for sectors most targeted by cyber threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rpmbi7d6:" popover="auto" Security</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document outlines the evolving cybercrime landscape, with style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">“Why It’s Critical to Have an Integrated Development Methodology for Edge AI,...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save “Why It’s Critical to Have an Integrated Development Methodology for Edge AI,... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R7mhmci7d6:" popovertarget=":R7mhmci7d6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R7mhmci7d6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R7mhmci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R7mhmci7d6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/embeddedvision">Edge AI and Vision Alliance</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">For the full video of this presentation, please visit: https://www.edge-ai-vision.com/2025/06/why-its-critical-to-have-an-integrated-development-methodology-for-edge-ai-a-presentation-from-lattice-semiconductor/

Sreepada Hegade, Director of ML Systems and Software at Lattice Semiconductor, presents the “Why It’s Critical to Have an Integrated Development Methodology for Edge AI” tutorial at the May 2025 Embedded Vision Summit.

The deployment of neural networks near sensors brings well-known advantages such as lower latency, privacy and reduced overall system cost—but also brings significant challenges that complicate development. These challenges can be addressed effectively by choosing the right solution and design methodology. The low-power FPGAs from Lattice are well poised to enable efficient edge implementation of models, while Lattice’s proven development methodology helps to mitigate the challenges and risks associated with edge model deployment.

In this presentation, Hegade explains the importance of an integrated framework that tightly consolidates different aspects of edge AI development, including training, quantization of networks for edge deployment, integration with sensors and inferencing. He also illustrates how Lattice’s simplified tool flow helps to achieve the best trade-off between power, performance and efficiency using low-power FPGAs for edge deployment of various AI workloads.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":Rhmci7d6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rhmci7d6"></div><div class="separator
